author: wsjcom
title: Excess Money Growth and Spending Drive Inflation
text: Regarding “Capital Account: Forces That Could Revive Inflation Are Lurking” (U.S. News, March 1): One may want to consider that the M2 money supply was growing at an 8% year-over-year rate by the beginning of 1966 and that aggregate spending (nominal GDP) had been growing at an average 8.6% over the preceding three years. With spending growth that fast over a sustained period, there should be no wonder that inflation accelerated back then. In contrast, M2 is up only 4.2% over the past year and nominal spending has grown at an average rate of only 3.6% over the past three years. As we saw in the 1980s and onward, we shall...
